ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

TERRORIST ATTACKS AGAINST USA
(Impact on Singapore economy)


    1. Mrs Lim Hwee Hua asked the Minister for Trade and Industry whether there will be an adverse impact from the unfortunate bombing incidents in the United States of America on Singapore's economic prospects and, if so, whether the Government will consider implementing further measures to help Singaporeans and businesses cope with the worsening downturn.

    2. Mr Tay Beng Chuan asked the Minister for Trade and Industry, in view of the recent devastating terrorist attacks against the United States of America, whether his Ministry can (i) provide statistics regarding the extent of their negative impact on the Singapore economy; and (ii) introduce further measures to help the Singapore economy should it be badly affected by the events.

    The Minister for Trade and Industry (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Mr Speaker, Sir, with your permission, I would like to take Question Nos. 1 and 2 together.

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: The recent terrorist attacks against the US are bound to impact the global economy. It has already caused significant disruptions to the US economy. The financial, insurance and airline industries are badly hit, although the interest rate cuts by the US Federal Reserve and the European Central Bank have helped to cushion the shock to financial markets.

    Prior to this event, there were some indications that the US economy might be close to bottoming out, but the September 11 attacks have diminished markedly the prospects of an early recovery. Consumer confidence and spending are expected to decline, increasing the risk of a US and a global recession significantly. The

Column: 2048

Singapore economy will be adversely affected.

    In Singapore, the immediate impact of the attacks was felt by our financial markets. The Straits Times Industrial Index fell by 7.3% while the Singapore dollar rose by 1.1% against the US dollar on 12th September as investors sold off the US dollar and stocks affected by the attacks. Air and sea transport was held up temporarily when the US closed its airports following the attack. Our export-oriented sectors like manufacturing, tourism and transport services will slow further as a result of weaker US demand in the short-term.

    The situation is still fluid and will depend on how events unfold in the coming months. The chain of events set off by the terrorist attacks has not yet fully played out, as the US considers its response, and as terrorist groups undoubtedly plan further moves. But the events last week have already changed the world. There will be greater uncertainties, and all economic forecasts will have to be reviewed. What is clear is that an economic recovery in the short term is unlikely. At this point, we expect our overall economic growth this year to become negative. Singaporeans must therefore be prepared for a more prolonged downturn.

    Over the last few months, the Government has been working on a second package of additional measures which might be needed to help ease the burden on companies and Singaporeans. The World Trade Centre attacks have increased the urgency of the second package and the scale of measures required. We are still finalising the package. The Finance Minister will address the question on the timing of the package in his reply.

    Mrs Lim Hwee Hua (Marine Parade): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to ask the Minister a supplementary question in terms of commenting conceptually on the extent of pump priming that the Government would consider in the circumstances.

Column: 2049



    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not think we are ready yet to announce the details of the package but conceptually there will be a modest amount of pump priming.

    Mr Leong Horn Kee (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Sir, may I ask the Minister whether his Ministry has now revised the GDP forecast for the whole year? I think the last forecast was minus 1.5%.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: We expect the flash forecast to be out on 7th October and when that forecast is out, we will also revise our GDP estimate for this year.

    Mr Hawazi Daipi (Sembawang): Sir, in a worst case scenario, how many jobs does the Minister expect to be lost as companies are directly affected by the downturn?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, the situation is still fluid because the dust of the recent disaster has not yet settled. The markets are still volatile. I think it is too early for us to be overly sure of what the ultimate impact would be. The war has not yet started. We do not know how long it will last and what all the consequences will be. We are on the pessimistic side, so we expect unemployment this year and next year to be worse than what we had earlier projected. As to how much worse, it is premature to say.

    Mr Zulkifli Bin Baharudin (Nominated Member): Sir, as in the US, which has announced a bail-out package for its airline industry, would the Minister consider bailing out SIA should this become necessary, at least to save jobs because SIA has announced plans to retrench some workers?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: On the issue of insurance, Government has already taken a quick decision yesterday.

    On preserving jobs in the airline industry by Government subsidy, I think that would be a very bad principle. I do not see at this point in time any request for a bail-out of SIA.

Column: 2050



    Mr Leong Horn Kee: Sir, I am not asking for a bail-out package but I want to ask the Minister whether he would target specific industries that would be more affected particularly by this impact of the terrorist attacks on the US, for example, airline-related industry, tourism, insurance and others that are more badly affected.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not think we should be reacting to what might be transient changes because of the terrorist attacks in New York and Washington. There is naturally an over-reaction and many people have reduced their travels. Many meetings have been cancelled and this has had an immediate impact on airlines, hotel and convention business. The dust will settle and things will assume a certain normality and we will have to analyse the situation then and decide what our appropriate responses should be.

Column: 2050

OFF-BUDGET MEASURES


    3. Mr Leong Horn Kee asked the Minister for Finance, in view of the deteriorating economy, when will the Government announce and implement further off-Budget measures to assist Singaporeans and local industries affected by the economic downturn.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Speaker, Sir, when the $2.2 billion off-Budget package was announced in July this year, we said that the Government would do more to assist Singaporeans if the global economic situation worsened in the coming months.

    In the intervening months, leading indicators suggest that the economy has worsened further and it is likely that the third quarter results will be substantially weaker. The Minister for Trade and Industry has also noted that the events in the United States due to terrorist attacks would depress the global economy further. So the outlook is pretty gloomy.

    Government has therefore been working on a second, more substantial, off-Budget package, which will be finalised when the third quarter results are

Column: 2051

known around mid-October. At that time, the full impact of the terrorist attacks on the US and its impact on our economy will be clearer.

    Mr Leong Horn Kee: Sir, may I ask the Minister whether he has a more definite date as to when the off-Budget measures would be announced and if the flash estimates can be ready earlier, could the off-Budget measures be announced earlier so as to help the industries and Singaporeans?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: As I said, the estimates will be available around mid-October. I do not think, at this time, I want to give a specific date when the second package will be announced, but it will be done as soon as practicable.

Column: 2051

IN-PRINCIPLE AGREEMENT WITH MALAYSIA ON
OUTSTANDING BILATERAL ISSUES

(Assessment)


    4. Mr Inderjit Singh asked the Prime Minister whether Singapore got a fair deal out of the recent agreement with Malaysia on the outstanding bilateral issues.

    5. Mr Noris Ong Chin Guan asked the Prime Minister if he will give an assessment of the recent in-principle agreement with Malaysia, announced by the Senior Minister and the Malaysian Prime Minister.

    6. Mr Tay Beng Chuan asked the Prime Minister when will the price increase to 45 sen per 1,000 gallons for the purchase of raw water from Malaysia take effect and whether it will significantly affect the retail price of water in Singapore.

    The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar) (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I have your permission to take the three questions by Mr Inderjit Singh, Mr Noris Ong Chin Guan and Mr Tay Beng Chuan together as they are related?

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

Column: 2052



    Prof. Jayakumar: Sir, let me first sketch the background to the recent positive developments in our discussions on the bilateral package. Senior Minister visited Kuala Lumpur last year in August, with Prime Minister Goh's agreement, to try and narrow the differences over the outstanding bilateral issues. Following discussions with Dr Mahathir, Senior Minister had written to Tun Daim regarding Singapore's proposals.

    The next step came, in February this year, when Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister Abdullah Badawi visited Singapore and discussed with Prime Minister Goh the package of outstanding issues. At this meeting, Prime Minister Goh agreed in-principle to Malaysia's request to move their KTM railway station from Tanjong Pagar to Kranji, and to have the KTM trains run in an underground tunnel from Johor to Kranji, as part of the larger package of issues. They both agreed on the need to resolve these outstanding issues on the package as soon as possible.

    Shortly after Deputy Prime Minister Abdullah Badawi's visit, Senior Minister received a reply from Dr Mahathir in March 2001 regarding Singapore's proposals. Members will recall that I told the House on 13th March that our preliminary study showed that there were variations on some points between Dr Mahathir's reply and Senior Minister's understanding with Dr Mahathir during his visit to Kuala Lumpur last year. I added, however, that at first blush, the difference did not appear that great.

    Senior Minister's recent visit to KL was a follow-up to Dr Mahathir's reply. After consulting Prime Minister Goh, Senior Minister visited KL again to continue discussions on the package.

    I now turn to the outcome of the most recent discussions between Senior Minister and Dr Mahathir. As Senior Minister has made clear in his comprehensive press conferences in KL, there is now accord on the basic skeletal or framework agreement, which would form the basis to resolve the outstanding issues.

Column: 2053



    This framework agreement, firstly, spells out the elements of the package; secondly, indicates the areas where there is agreement on both sides; and thirdly, sets out areas where further discussions are needed to close the gaps.

    To recapitulate, the key elements of the broad agreement are the long-term supply of water to Singapore beyond 2061, implementation of the POA, the proposal for a new bridge to replace the existing Causeway, use of Malaysian airspace by the RSAF and the early withdrawal of CPF funds by West Malaysians.

    On water, for the period 2011 to 2061, Malaysia has offered to provide Singapore with an additional 100 mgd of treated water to replace the 1961 Water Agreement, which expires in 2011. While Singapore has agreed to the quantity, Singapore has proposed that this continue to be provided in raw form as Singapore has the necessary filtration capacity.

    From 2061 to 2161, Malaysia has offered to provide 350 mgd of water to Singapore - 100 mgd raw and 250 mgd treated water. Singapore has agreed to 350 mgd of water, but has proposed to draw 150 mgd of raw water and 200 mgd of treated water.

    As regards the source, Singapore's position is that the source of additional water to be provided from 2011, and from 2061-2161 must be the Johor River. Furthermore, the production of treated water to be supplied to Singapore after 2061 will be done jointly between Singapore and Malaysia.

    As for the price of water, for the existing supply of 350 mgd of raw water under the 1961 and 1962 Water Agreements, Singapore has agreed to a revision of the price of raw water purchased. Singapore has proposed to revise the price from 3 sen to 45 sen per 1,000 gallons.

    For the additional raw water to be supplied from 2011-2061, and from 2061-2161, Singapore has agreed to the price of

Column: 2054

60 sen per 1,000 gallons, to be reviewed every five years for inflation.

    Mr Tay Beng Chuan asked when will the price increase to 45 sen commence, and whether it will significantly affect the retail price of water in Singapore. The answer to that is the proposed price increase will commence only after full agreement on the package has been finalised with Malaysia, and only after it is signed by both Prime Ministers. The increase from 3 sen to 45 sen is, of course, significant. However, the retail price of water also includes other components, including manpower costs, treatment and distribution costs, and the Water Conservation Tax. Therefore, any increase in the overall retail price of water, arising from the higher raw water price paid to Johor, should be manageable.

    On the POA, let me first stress that the new agreement will not supersede the 1990 Points of Agreement, unless they are explicitly varied as part of the wider package negotiations.

    As I have mentioned earlier, Singapore agreed for the KTM station to be relocated from Tanjong Pagar to Kranji, with the KTM trains running in an underground tunnel from Johor to the Kranji railway station. Malaysia will pay for the cost of building the underground tunnel.

    The rail Customs, Immigration and Quarantine (CIQ) facilities will move from its current location to Kranji following the completion of the railway tunnel. Pending the shift to Kranji, we have proposed that the KTM railway station will be located temporarily at Woodlands.

    The plot of land at Tanjong Pagar currently occupied by KTM will be exchanged for a plot at Shenton Way of equivalent value for joint development.

    In addition, Singapore has agreed to variations of the POA to include 12 lots at Bukit Timah together with the original three land parcels to be jointly developed.

    On the causeway and the bridge, Singapore has agreed to Malaysia's proposal for a bridge to be built between

Column: 2055

Singapore and Malaysia. However, Singapore proposed that the demolition of the causeway take place after 2007, when both the bridge and the tunnel have been completed and provided the tolls charged at the bridge do not exceed the present toll rates at the causeway adjusted for inflation.

    Singapore will reclaim its side to the maximum and build its side of the bridge to meet the Malaysian side at the boundary. Singapore's toll rates at the bridge will match that of Malaysia.

    As regards airspace, Malaysia will reinstate all the arrangements and understandings for RSAF aircraft to use Malaysia's airspace (including the South China Sea Training Areas) for transit and training.

    As regards CPF, Singapore will allow the early withdrawal, on an individual basis phased over two years, of the CPF monies of West Malaysians who have left Singapore permanently.

    Mr Speaker, as Members can see, there has been progress. However, many details still have to be sorted out by the officials of both countries to be put in a form of words into an Agreement which the respective Prime Ministers can agree.

    Let me stress two important points. Firstly, all the items are to be considered as part of a package. Secondly, the skeletal or framework agreement has to be completed by settling the details that remain to be resolved.

    The Member for Ang Mo Kio has asked whether Singapore had received a fair deal from the broad agreement reached between Senior Minister and Dr Mahathir. This question has also been raised in the media. Senior Minister had dealt with this issue during his press conference in KL, but I shall also touch on it.

    Let me first say, Sir, that, in the nature of international negotiations, the broad agreement reached between Singapore and Malaysia was a compromise made by both sides to move the long-standing bilateral issues forward. Having been

Column: 2056

subjects of contention for so long, the deal marks a psychological breakthrough in our bilateral negotiations. It shows that despite sporadic problems in our relations, both countries recognise the value of cooperation and each country has a stake in the other's stability and growth. I believe this will place relations on a surer footing.

    Viewed in that context, Singapore has decided to try to reach an agreement with Malaysia. Some of the items are not balanced in our favour like reducing our water request for some 750 mgd to 350 mgd without any reduction of the concessions we are making.

    The key question Singaporeans should ask ourselves is this: Are we better off concluding a deal, or by allowing such outstanding issues to fester? I think both sides are better off with the outstanding issues resolved. We decided it was best to have a deal with Malaysia.

    While we have decided to reach a deal with Malaysia, let me assure Members that we will continue with our plans for desalination, as well as water reclamation to produce NEWater, a process which involves micro-filtration followed by Reverse Osmosis based on membrane technology. We can expect advancements in membrane technology to continue to reduce the costs of these two alternative sources of water.

    Sir, this package will put behind us the outstanding issues and it can have positive effects for both Singapore and Malaysia.

    Mr Inderjit Singh (Ang Mo Kio): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have three supplementary questions. The first question is on the issue of CPF withdrawal. Is this a total withdrawal by an individual, or is it going to be transferred to the Malaysian EPF? And related to that, would not this create a disadvantage or unfair situation for Singaporeans who cannot withdraw their CPF until retirement? What would be the rules that would not create this disadvantaged position for us?

    The second question is on the 12 new plots of land that have been released in

Column: 2057

place of the relocation of the railway. Does the Minister have the current market value of the 12 pieces of land?

    The third question is, while we have got the broad strokes of agreement, when do we expect the agreement to be finally concluded, as we know the POA was something that we thought would have been implemented, but was not implemented? Will this be another example of something that has been discussed, but not implementable?

    Prof. Jayakumar: I thank Mr Inderjit Singh for his questions. The first question concerns CPF, and the answer to the question is that it is a withdrawal by individuals.

    Whether it will put Singaporeans at a disadvantage, let me say that, as I mentioned in my main answer, the withdrawal is for Malaysians who were working here and who have returned to Malaysia permanently. So that would be an important consideration.

    On the question whether I have with me the current market value of the 12 plots at Bukit Timah, I do not have that particular detail with me.

    The third question was, with regard to a general point, whether we expect any new agreement to be implemented considering our experience with the POA. Let me say that, as with any international negotiation with any country, we must approach the deal in good faith that both sides will keep to the terms of the agreement when we do settle the details and finalise the agreement, and it is signed.
